attributes.title: The Effects of Exposure to Information about UBI

q1.value: The Effects of Exposure to Information about UBI

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Previous studies have tested the effects of exposing people to policy-relevant information (Gilens 2001; Lawrence and Sides 2014; Barrera et al. 2018; Hopkins et al. 2019). Some of these studies have even found that exposure to relevant information can affect policy preferences regarding ideal levels of foreign aid and immigration (Gilens 2001; Grigorieff et al. 2018). While the insights from this literature are valuable, many of the studies do not explicitly provide opposing arguments in their stimuli (e.g., fictitious news articles). In such cases, the causal effect estimates are arguably inflated, because in less complex information environments, people may be more likely to be influenced by exposure to new facts. Conversely, when facing complex information environments such as those presented in many real news articles, people may be more likely to default to their original policy positions. In this current study, which is about public attitudes toward universal basic income (UBI), my research design addresses the foregoing issue. Subjects in the control group will see a news article that includes an explanation of UBI and arguments for and against UBI. For more information on my research design, please see Section C3 and the associated PAP (separate document). My main research questions are listed below. (1) Can exposure to information (e.g., size of the national debt) improve people’s factual knowledge? Does the effect of receiving this information depend on the respondent’s partisanship and educational attainment? (2) Can exposure to information affect people’s attitudes toward relevant public policies? Does the effect of exposure to information depend on whether they were reminded of arguments that support their original position? (3) How does the type of information in an article (e.g., counter-attitudinal) affect people’s perceptions of the fairness and accuracy of the article? Do these attitudes moderate the effects of receiving the information?

q16.value: Hypotheses 1-3 are about the effects of information (e.g., facts, predictions), and Hypotheses 4-6 are about how respondents react to counter-attitudinal information. (H1) Exposure to information about the current size of the national debt will reduce factual misperceptions. However, this effect will be greater among conservatives, Republicans, and those with college degrees (regardless of partisanship). (H2) Exposure to information about the expected consequences of automation will increase subjective job insecurity. This effect will be greater among those without college degrees/those who have blue-collar jobs (or if someone in their immediate family has a blue-collar job). (H3): Exposure to relevant information will affect policy preferences. First, exposure to information about the rise of automation will increase public support for UBI (H3a). Second, exposure to information about the size of the national debt will reduce support for UBI (H3b). (H4): Reminding respondents of arguments that support their original positions will reduce the effects of counter-attitudinal information on their policy preferences. (H5): Exposure to counter-attitudinal information (in the absence of attitude-consistent information) will have heterogeneous effects on the perceived fairness and accuracy of the article. Among partisans with college degrees, exposure to counter-attitudinal information will lead to a decrease in the perceived fairness of the article, but not in the perceived accuracy of the article (H5a). Among partisans without college degrees, exposure to counter-attitudinal information will lead to a decrease in the perceived fairness and accuracy of the article (H5b). (H6) The effects of counter-attitudinal information on policy preferences will be smaller among those who perceived the article as being both unfair and inaccurate. (H7) Partisans (high motivation) with college degrees (high capacity) will be more likely to cite relevant information (e.g., facts, statistics) to justify their preferences in the free-response section.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, I will implement an online survey experiment in which 1,200 subjects will be randomly assigned to one of 6 groups. Subjects in each group will be asked to read a fictitious news article about UBI. The details of each condition are listed below. Control: UBI explanation + pro/con arguments Treatment 1: UBI explanation + pro/con arguments + pro-UBI fact Treatment 2: UBI explanation + pro/con arguments + anti-UBI fact Treatment 3: UBI explanation + pro-UBI argument + pro-UBI fact Treatment 4: UBI explanation + anti-UBI argument + anti-UBI fact Treatment 5: UBI explanation + pro/con arguments + pro-UBI fact + anti-UBI fact The sample size (~200 per group) was determined by a power analysis, which assumed a power of 0.8. The sample will be nationally representative with respect to ACS demographic standards: race/ethnicity, age, gender. The sample will be provided by Bovitz Inc., a survey research firm with offices in Los Angeles and New York City. Bovitz is led by Greg Bovitz, who is a political scientist by training. For more details, please refer to my pre-analysis plan (PAP).

attributes.title: A Social Ecological Approach to Adolescent Mental Health in the Digital Age - An ABCD Study Analysis

q1.value: A Social Ecological Approach to Adolescent Mental Health in the Digital Age

q3.value:
Adolescence is a dynamic time in development which is associated with enhanced opportunities and vulnerabilities due to vast physical, psychological, and social changes. A rising prevalence of depression and anxiety among adolescents in the U.S., with approximately 22% with severe impairments (Bose, 2017; NIMH, 2019), has evoked growing concerns around causes for this rise, especially considering the digital age. Adolescents are the largest adopters of technology, with approximately 95% having access to a mobile device, 71% using one or more social media platforms, and 45% claiming to be online “almost constantly” (Pew Research Center, 2018). While many studies have shown associations between screen time and poor mental health outcomes (Kırcaburun et al., 2018; Lemola et al., 2015; McBride, 2017; Sampasa-Kanyinga & Lewis, 2015; Stiglic & Viner, 2019; Twenge & Campbell, 2018; Twenge et al., 2018), recent reviews of the literature show mixed and inconsistencies in these findings (Best et al., 2014; Odgers, 2018; Rideout, 2018; Sarmiento et al., 2018; Wartella et al., 2016). 

A recent rigorous analysis of large-scale datasets by Orben and Przybylski (2019) revealed associations between screen time and wellbeing in adolescents suggesting small effects sizes which can be comparable to many other possible and unrelated correlates to mental health outcomes in adolescents. This posits a greater consideration that must be made in statistical inferences in efforts to address the complex nature in the rise of internalizing behaviors such as depressive and anxiety symptoms in youth. 

Many established lines of research investigating predictors, beyond individual factors such as screen time (Odgers, 2018) and cognitive functioning (Shortt & Spence, 2006), to poor mental health outcomes in adolescents include family (Sander & McCarty, 2005) and peer factors (Garland & Fitzgerald, 1998; MacPhee & Andrews, 2006), school functioning (Juvonen et al., 2000; Fröjd et al., 2008), neighborhood (Aneshensel & Sucoff, 1996) and community factors (Huynh & Fuligni, 2010). This multi-level perspective echoes the social ecological framework (Bronfenbrenner & Morris, 2006; Stokols, 2018), which recognizes the interplay of the various ecologies, proximal and distal to the individual, on mental health during this developmental period. The objective of this study is to investigate the social ecological factors associated with adolescent mental health in the digital age. Using a multimodal baseline dataset from the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) study (Volkow et al., 2017), we will be able to characterize correlates to mental health outcomes of a diverse U.S. adolescent cohort, inclusive of the various ecological factors. The aims of this study are threefold: (1) to evaluate the associations between screen time and internalizing behaviors, (2) to evaluate the associations between multi-level ecological factors previously identified as risk factors for increases in internalizing behaviors among adolescents, and (3) explore differences in these associations stratified by socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups.

q4.value:
Aim 1: Evaluate the relation between screen time and internalizing behaviors in early adolescence. 

H1a: Greater screen time in early adolescence will have small positive association to increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H1b: The positive association between screen time and internalizing behaviors will be stronger (moderated) among females. 

Aim 2: Evaluate social ecological factors previously known to be associated with poor mental health outcomes/internalizing behaviors

H2a: Poor family dynamics will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2b: Poor peer relationships will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2c: Poor school functioning will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2d: Lower levels of neighborhood safety will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2e: Heightened levels of perceived discrimination will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 


Aim 3 (Exploratory): Explore unique SES and racial/ethnic group differences on the associations between multi-level ecological factors and poor mental health outcomes in adolescents.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study draws from the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study, which has been designed as an open-access dataset through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The ABCD study is designed to be a multimodal longitudinal study uniquely capturing the development of adolescences through neuroimaging, biospecimen, neurocognition, mental and physical health measures, and equivalent parental self-reported measures across 10 years and 21 sites in the United States. Details of the adolescent sampling for recruitment can be found in prior publication (Garavan et al., 2018). 

For this particular analysis, I will be utilizing the self-reported measures of demographic information, psychological wellbeing, cognitive functioning, screen time, family dynamics, school functioning, neighborhood safety and community environment.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
The proposed data analysis will approach the currently available baseline cross-sectional data (2.0.1) of this 10-year longitudinal dataset with a more holistic approach to understanding correlates and trends of development and wellbeing across a diverse group of US adolescents. This in efforts to promote research with an open-science framework. To ensure the blinding of patterns and summary statistics of variable of interest beyond demographic information, we will be utilizing the Data Exploration Analysis Portal (DEAP) which has taken measures to prevent post hoc hypothesis testing. Exploratory analysis will be conducted to investigate differences in mental health outcomes stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups. 

To my knowledge there have not been studies published yet looking at direct relations between screen time and internalizing behaviors using this dataset, alongside the interplay of multi-level ecological variables related to mental health outcomes in adolescence.

question.value: Recruitment for this study is across 21 catchment areas in the mainland United States and data from children and parents are stored in the main data management site of University of California, San Diego. As a part of the open-access data initiative, the NIH has made the deidentified data publicly available for researchers globally. The data was obtained through data user agreement between NIH and UCI and an exempt data analysis protocol is in place for this specific study analysis, as there will be no direct interaction with the study participants and only data will be analyzed.

q13.value: The sample size for the baseline data of this adolescent cohort is 11,875. Parent/caregiver data is also collected, thus the sample size of adults in this study are 11,875 individuals at baseline data collection. This number is expected to decrease when accounting for missing data, which will be analyzed after pre-registration.

q14.value: This sample size was over sampled with the anticipated attrition rates (10%) in a 10-year longitudinal study of this magnitude. To capture the national diversity of the adolescent population in the U.S., a multi-stage probability sampling design of schools around each study site was conducted. There was an oversampling of African American and other races and relative under-sampling of Caucasian and Hispanics in order to achieve a more optimal racial/ethnic distribution in this cohort of adolescents (Garavan et al., 2018).

question.value: N/A

**Please refer to attached document for details of each measure. 

Outcome(s): Internalizing Behaviors (CBCL); Mental Health Diagnosis (KSADS)

Predictors/Correlates: Screen Time; Cognitive Functioning (NIH Toolbox) Parental Monitoring Survey; Youth Family Environment Scale; Resiliency Survey (Peer Relationships); School Risk and Protective Factors; Brief Problem Monitoring; Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey; Discrimination Measure

Covariates: Youth Demographics (age, gender, race/ethnicity); Parent Demographics (SES, highest education level, marital status)
n/a

Descriptive and frequency statistics will be initially conducted to understand the demographic and internalizing behavior (e.g. depressive and anxiety symptom) distributions of this study cohort. 

Bivariate correlations will be conducted to characterize the associations between multi-level ecological factors and internalizing behaviors. Effect sizes will be reported to compare the magnitude of the associations of potential predictors of internalizing behaviors. Multiple linear regression analysis will be performed to further investigate the associations between the ecological factors and internalizing behaviors above and beyond covariate demographic factors and relative to the factors of each ecological level to identify unique predictive factors of screen time. 

**Please see attached variable document for measure information
Outcome variables: internalizing behaviors (CBCL, KSADS) 
Predictor variables: Individual factors (Screen Time, Cognitive Functioning), family dynamics (Family Environment Survey, Parental monitoring Survey), peer relationships (Resilience Survey), school functioning (Brief Problem Monitoring – Teacher reported), neighborhood environment (Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey), and community environment (Discrimination Survey). 
Covariates: child demographics (age, sex given at birth, race/ethnicity, pubertal development); parent demographics (family SES, highest parent education, marital status)

As an exploratory aim, run descriptives and bivariate correlations will be conducted stratified by socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups. We will conduct similar multiple regression models stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups, then test potential interaction effects.

registration_responses.q8.question:
This study draws from the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study, which has been designed as an open-access dataset through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The ABCD study is designed to be a multimodal longitudinal study uniquely capturing the development of adolescences through neuroimaging, biospecimen, neurocognition, mental and physical health measures, and equivalent parental self-reported measures across 10 years and 21 sites in the United States. Details of the adolescent sampling for recruitment can be found in prior publication (Garavan et al., 2018). 

For this particular analysis, I will be utilizing the self-reported measures of demographic information, psychological wellbeing, cognitive functioning, screen time, family dynamics, school functioning, neighborhood safety and community environment.

The data was obtained through data user agreement between NIH and UCI and an exempt data analysis protocol is in place for this specific study analysis, as there will be no direct interaction with the study participants and only data will be analyzed.

registration_responses.q19.question:
Descriptive and frequency statistics will be initially conducted to understand the demographic and internalizing behavior (e.g. depressive and anxiety symptom) distributions of this study cohort. 

Bivariate correlations will be conducted to characterize the associations between multi-level ecological factors and internalizing behaviors. Effect sizes will be reported to compare the magnitude of the associations of potential predictors of internalizing behaviors. Multiple linear regression analysis will be performed to further investigate the associations between the ecological factors and internalizing behaviors above and beyond covariate demographic factors and relative to the factors of each ecological level to identify unique predictive factors of screen time. 

**Please see attached variable document for measure information
Outcome variables: internalizing behaviors (CBCL, KSADS) 
Predictor variables: Individual factors (Screen Time, Cognitive Functioning), family dynamics (Family Environment Survey, Parental monitoring Survey), peer relationships (Resilience Survey), school functioning (Brief Problem Monitoring – Teacher reported), neighborhood environment (Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey), and community environment (Discrimination Survey). 
Covariates: child demographics (age, sex given at birth, race/ethnicity, pubertal development); parent demographics (family SES, highest parent education, marital status)

As an exploratory aim, run descriptives and bivariate correlations will be conducted stratified by socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups. We will conduct similar multiple regression models stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups, then test potential interaction effects.

attributes.title: Explaining Faking in a Job Applicant Sample

summary.value:
Please see attached document for all details of this preregistration. 
This document serves as a pre-registration of hypotheses and analyses. The aim of this study is to better understand faking of job applicants by investigating the (possible) underlying cognitions. At the time of writing this preregistration document, all data have been collected and the responses regarding the Ability to Identify Criteria have been coded. So far, no analyses have been conducted besides an investigation of sample demographics, comparisons between sample and population, variables’ mean values, distributions (i.e., histograms and tests for normality), and scale reliability. With this document, we aim to preregister the analyses to test our hypotheses and the reliability of the ATIC coding.

attributes.title: The Influence of Affective State on Intra-Day Alcohol Consumption: a Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: A systematic review of the effect of daily affective states on the quantity of alcohol consumed that day

q1.value: Anna Tovmasyan, Rebecca Monk, Derek Heim

q2.value: Research question: How does affective state during the day shapes alcohol consumption levels on that day?

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The following databases will be searched: PsycINFO, PsycARTICLES, Science Direct, Wiley Online Library, SCOPUS, PubMed, Web of Science, JSTOR. The following command will be used for searching: ("alcohol consumption" OR "drinking behavi*r) AND ("mood" OR "emotions" OR "affective states") NOT "disorders".
Additional articles will be located by reading the references of the retrieved articles. To gain a full understanding of the literature and control for unpublished non-significant findings, grey literature will be included in the review as well. This will be obtained by emailing research group leaders of labs conducting this kind of work.
The single outcome variable will be the amount of alcohol consumed on the day.
First, the quality appraisal of the obtained studies will be conducted. Then, the meta-analysis of the data will be carried out.

attributes.title: Trolls Just Want To Have Fun
attributes.description: This study details the correlation between the online act of "trolling" and the Dark Tetrad of Personality Traits. This is an observational study where data is collected from study subjects not randomly assigned to a treatment. The study design follows that of a repeated measure study and there is no blinding involved. Participants must be at least 18 years of age and sign a consent form prior to any activity. In order to collect data, participants will be asked to use the internet for gaming and/or social media usage. To analyze the data, a post-hoc test will be considered to figure significant difference in testing results.

q1.value: Trolls Just Want to Have Fun

q2.value: Brooke Billison, mallory burns, Allie Cotten, Kaylin Chauvin, Taylor Thigpen

q3.value: This study will compare the relationship between trolling and the Dark Tetrad of personality traits from two online studies. The purpose of this study is to create public awareness of online trolling which can be define as behaving in a destructive or disruptive manner in social settings on the internet with no apparent purpose.

q4.value:
H0: Dark personality traits is not an indicator to trolling behavior.
 
H1: Dark personality traits is an indicator to trolling behavior.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a repeated measure study. College students who are 18 years old or older in the United States will complete an online survey questionnaire regarding trolling and their online use. Participants will receive an 20% off Amazon coupon.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The inclusion criteria for this experiment is that subjects must be 18 years or older and must habitually utilize the internet for gaming and/or social networking. We will recruit by advertising to peers that fit the criteria and ask if they know anyone else who meets the criteria and who are willing to participate. Participants will receive a 20% off Amazon coupon. The study timeline will be however long the participant takes to complete the survey.

q13.value: This experiment will use around 400 participants. 400 participants being the minimum to replicate the original experiment.

question.value:
The 44- item Big Inventory is going to be use to assess personality traits: extraversion, agreeableness, neuroticism, and openness to experience. 

A second measure variable that will be assess is the dark personality traits: narcissism, malchievousness, and clinical psychopathy. The 27 item dark triad scale will be used to determine these traits in subjects. 
The third measure that will be measured is sadistic personality within the subjects. The 18-item comprehensive assessment of Sadistic tendencies will be used to measure this variable. 

A CAST item also is used to assess three varieties of sadistic tendencies: direct physical sadism, direct verbal sadism, and vicarious sadism. There will be 20 questions that will be rated on a 5 point likard scale from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). Total points for the test is 100, with 100 indicating high sadistic tendencies and 5 indicating low sadistic tendencies. 

Additionally there is also a section asking participants to quantify the amount of time they spend on the internet. This section will consist of questions like how many hours a day do you spend on the internet, how many hours a day do you spend commenting, and when you are on the internet what is the primary thing you use. 

Furthermore, participants are asked to rate their enjoyableness internet activities: chatting, debating, trolling, and making friends. They will rate themselves on a 7 point likerd scale 1 being (very unenjoyable and 7 very enjoyable). 

Finally the following questions will be asked on a 5 point likard scale (1 strongly disagree and 5 strongly agree) to address trolling experience and identification with trolling culture:  ‘‘I have sent people to shock websites for the lulz’’, ‘‘I like to troll people in forums or the comments section of websites’’, ‘‘I enjoy griefing other players in multiplayer games’’, and ‘‘The more beautiful and pure a thing is, the more satisfying it is to corrupt’’.

We would consider running a post-hoc test if there was a significant difference in the test results (ANOVA). We would do this to see exactly how much variance is between each of the personality traits.

q21.value: Since our hypothesis is testing if there is or is not a difference, we will have to run a two-tailed t-test. If the difference in the results shows a significance difference larger than 0.05, then we will assume that the results are significantly different.

q22.value: If the sample size ends up being too small, we will take that into consideration when comparing the results, but data will not be excluded. Outliers will be handled accordingly.

q23.value: We will have to discount the data set from the subject if there are incomplete or missing parts.

q24.value: We may wish to run some post-hoc tests to see if there are any differences in the personality traits themselves, but this is not a requirement for our study.

attributes.title: Examining the similarity between greenwashing and pinkwashing effects
attributes.description: This study examines whether attributing pinkwashing to a company influences the consumer perceptions of such a company. It extends currently available research on greenwashing (within the CSR subfield), which shows that attributing greenwashing to a company increases consumer skepticism and lowers purchase intentions and brand attitude, amongst other things. The study aims to find whether these effects can be extended to pinkwashing as well.

q2.value:
H1 – Directly attributing pinkwashing to a company causes more negative consumer perceptions of that company than not directly attributing pinkwashing to a company.
H2 – Indirectly attributing pinkwashing to a company (by mentioning the practice of pinkwashing within the industry in which the company operates) causes more negative consumer perceptions of a company than not indirectly attributing pinkwashing to a company.
H3 - When pinkwashing is directly attributed to a company, consumers will develop more negative perceptions of that company when it is also indirectly attributed to the company than when it is not also indirectly attributed to the company.
H4 - When pinkwashing is directly attributed to a company, consumers with an LGBTQ+ identity will develop more negative perceptions towards the company than those without an LGBTQ+ identity.
H5 - When pinkwashing is indirectly attributed to a company, consumers with an LGBTQ+ identity will develop more negative perceptions towards a company within that industry than those without an LGBTQ+ identity.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2x2 factorial between subjects design, with 2 factors (direct attribution and indirect attribution) which each have 2 levels (is attributed and is not attributed).

q7.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks, using Qualtrics.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will mainly be recruited through the network of the author. In addition, some LGBTQ+ interest groups will also be contacted in an attempt to distribute the survey through their network. Participants must be at least 18 years old. They will not be compensated for participating in the study.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 240 participants (at minimum). However, we will attempt to recruit up to 300, because the 240 participants might not include enough LGBTQ+ individuals.

q12.value: Our goal was to obtain at least .80 as a power. Using a sample size calculator from University of British Colombia, this generated an aim of at least 240 participants.

question.value: The two independent variables in the research design are independent and dependent attribution. These are manipulated by modifying the stimulus material (a fabricated news article) in such a way that a company is either directly accused of pinkwashing (or not) or it is indirectly connected to pinkwashing (or not) by mentioning the practice of pinkwashing in the industry.

The study will measure three dependent outcome variables:
- Consumer skepticism, which will be measured using a four-item 7-point Likert scale asking the consumers whether or not they believe the company mentioned in the stimulus material is sincere
- Purchase intention, which will be measured using a five-item 7-point bipolar scale asking the participants which word best describes their purchase intention regarding the product mentioned in the stimulus material
- Attitude towards the brand, which will be measured using a five-item 7-point bipolar scale asking the participants which word best describes their attitude towards the brand mentioned in the stimulus material

In addition, the following variables will also be measured:
- LGBTQ+ identity, which will be measured by asking participants whether they identify as LGBTQ+
- Acceptance of LGBTQ+ individuals, which will be measured by asking the participants to what extend they are accepting of people having an LGBTQ+ identity (5-point)
- Product involvement, which will be measured using a 4-item 5-point bipolar scale asking to what extend the participants feel that the product mentioned in the stimulus material is important to them
- Buying frequency of the product, which will be measured by asking how often participants buy the product mentioned in the stimulus material
- General purchase intentions, which will be measured similar to the purchase intention, only as a general measure towards the product category, rather than the specific product presented in the stimulus material.

We will use the following statistical models to test each hypothesis:
- H1: MANOVA with "direct attribution" factor
- H2: MANOVA with "indirect attribution" factor
- H3: Factorial MANOVA with "direct attribution" factor and "indirect attribution" as interaction effect
- H4: Factorial MANOVA with "direct attribution" factor and "LGBTQ+ identity" as interaction effect
- H5: Factorial MANOVA with "indirect attribution" factor and "LGBTQ+ identity" as interaction effect

q18.value: There are no additional transformations required.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Bonferroni test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q20.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis. Any data collected from individuals above 18 years old (who, for example, did not read the consent form) will be excluded.

q21.value: All questions will be required in the survey; therefore, any participant who completes the survey will not have an incomplete data entry. Participants which do not finish the survey will not be included.

q22.value: We will look for relationships between the demographic variables and the primary outcome measures of consumer perceptions. In addition, we might also test for relationships between the moderating variables LGBTQ+ acceptance, general purchase intention, product involvement and buying frequency, and the primary outcome measure of consumer perceptions.

registration_responses.q21: All questions will be required in the survey; therefore, any participant who completes the survey will not have an incomplete data entry. Participants which do not finish the survey will not be included.
registration_responses.q22: We will look for relationships between the demographic variables and the primary outcome measures of consumer perceptions. In addition, we might also test for relationships between the moderating variables LGBTQ+ acceptance, general purchase intention, product involvement and buying frequency, and the primary outcome measure of consumer perceptions.
registration_responses.q6.question: 2x2 factorial between subjects design, with 2 factors (direct attribution and indirect attribution) which each have 2 levels (is attributed and is not attributed).
registration_responses.q10.question: Participants will mainly be recruited through the network of the author. In addition, some LGBTQ+ interest groups will also be contacted in an attempt to distribute the survey through their network. Participants must be at least 18 years old. They will not be compensated for participating in the study.
registration_responses.q14.question: The two independent variables in the research design are independent and dependent attribution. These are manipulated by modifying the stimulus material (a fabricated news article) in such a way that a company is either directly accused of pinkwashing (or not) or it is indirectly connected to pinkwashing (or not) by mentioning the practice of pinkwashing in the industry.
registration_responses.q15.question:
The study will measure three dependent outcome variables:
- Consumer skepticism, which will be measured using a four-item 7-point Likert scale asking the consumers whether or not they believe the company mentioned in the stimulus material is sincere
- Purchase intention, which will be measured using a five-item 7-point bipolar scale asking the participants which word best describes their purchase intention regarding the product mentioned in the stimulus material
- Attitude towards the brand, which will be measured using a five-item 7-point bipolar scale asking the participants which word best describes their attitude towards the brand mentioned in the stimulus material

In addition, the following variables will also be measured:
- LGBTQ+ identity, which will be measured by asking participants whether they identify as LGBTQ+
- Acceptance of LGBTQ+ individuals, which will be measured by asking the participants to what extend they are accepting of people having an LGBTQ+ identity (5-point)
- Product involvement, which will be measured using a 4-item 5-point bipolar scale asking to what extend the participants feel that the product mentioned in the stimulus material is important to them
- Buying frequency of the product, which will be measured by asking how often participants buy the product mentioned in the stimulus material
- General purchase intentions, which will be measured similar to the purchase intention, only as a general measure towards the product category, rather than the specific product presented in the stimulus material.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will use the following statistical models to test each hypothesis:
- H1: MANOVA with "direct attribution" factor
- H2: MANOVA with "indirect attribution" factor
- H3: Factorial MANOVA with "direct attribution" factor and "indirect attribution" as interaction effect
- H4: Factorial MANOVA with "direct attribution" factor and "LGBTQ+ identity" as interaction effect
- H5: Factorial MANOVA with "indirect attribution" factor and "LGBTQ+ identity" as interaction effect

attributes.title: Metaphors and Puns in Online Dating Profiles: Impressions about Profile Owner’s Personality and Attractiveness and Users’ Response Messages to Them
attributes.description:
The broad research questions of this study are:
-	Does the use of metaphors and puns in online dating profiles affect impressions that are formed about the profile owners’ attractiveness and dating intention and do personality perceptions mediate this relationship?
-	Do online daters accommodate to the use of metaphors and puns in dating profiles of others by using metaphors and puns in their response messages?
-	Is the degree of accommodation in response messages to metaphor and pun use in dating profiles moderated by the profile owner’s perceived attractiveness?

q1.value: Tess van der Zanden, Maria Mos, Alexander Schouten, Emiel Krahmer

q2.value:
H1a. Online dating profile texts including metaphors positively affect perceptions of profile owners’ intelligence which, in turn, positively affect perceptions of profile owner’s attractiveness and dating intention. 

H1b. Online dating profile texts including puns positively affect perceptions of profile owners’ intelligence and sense of humor which, in turn, positively affect perceptions of profile owner’s attractiveness and dating intention. 

H2a. Participants who respond to an online dating profile text with metaphors use more metaphors in their response messages than participants who respond to a profile text without metaphors. 

H2b. Participants who respond to an online dating profile text with puns use more puns in their response messages than participants who respond to a profile text without puns. 

H3a. The perceived attractiveness of a profile owner moderates the effect of writing a response message with metaphors to an online dating profile text with metaphors. 

H3b. The perceived attractiveness of a profile owner moderates the effect of writing a response message with puns to an online dating profile text with puns.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: When coding the response messages, coders will also be blinded to the condition for which the response message was written.

question.value:
This experiment contains a perception and a production task. For both parts of the study, we have a within-subjects design with three conditions: profile texts with two metaphors, profile texts with two puns, and profile texts with neither metaphors nor puns. The metaphors and puns included in the profile texts are pretested. The texts with metaphors scored significantly higher on metaphor identification than the texts without, and the same for pun identification for the texts with puns. 

Each participant will be randomly assigned to a list that includes three different profiles, one in each condition. Participants have to rate these three profiles that differ in content, the accompanied blurred profile picture, and the condition. The text content is similar for male and female profiles, but the pictures are blurred pictures of males or females. In total, there were 27 profiles for both males and females (3 texts x 3 conditions x 3 pictures). Based on the indicated sexual preference, participants will be presented with male or female profiles. To control for order effects, the order of profiles in which participants will be presented to the different conditions will be counterbalanced.

In the production task of this study, participants have to write response messages to all three profiles they evaluate, and thus to profiles in all three conditions.

q7.value: At the beginning of the experiment, participants will be randomly directed to one of the nine lists that are available per gender (randomly assigned but all equally presented; See Lists PreRegistration_MetaphorsPuns.xlsx). Each list contains three profiles, one from each condition (randomly assigned but all equally presented).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Our study investigates (1) how people rate profile owners with texts with/without metaphors or puns, and (2) whether participants use metaphors and puns when they respond to profiles with or without metaphors or puns. 
Both perception and production data will be collected online via a Qualtrics survey. Our participants will be adult members of online dating sites. We will collaborate with dating sites who will help us with participant recruitment, but are not involved in any further aspects of the study, such as the experimental setup or the study outcomes.  

The aim is to start the data collection in April 2020. The experiment will last about 15 minutes to complete and participation is on a voluntary basis. Participants will not be rewarded for their participation. 

First, participants will be welcomed and informed about the procedure of the experiment, and accordingly will answer some demographic questions (i.e. gender, sexual preference, age, level of education, Dutch as native language, years on dating site).

In the instruction, participants will be told that as researchers we are interested in how people assess and react to online dating profiles. After each profile, they are asked to answer some statements about the profile owner, that is, about their personality and attractiveness (on a seven-point Likert scale).

Participants are also instructed that after a profile is assessed, we ask them to write a short response message in response to the owner of this profile. Only when participants want to continue to the next profile with fewer than 20 words, they will receive the message that their messages should be approximately 30 words. When the response message is written, participants will answer one last yes/no question about their intention to date the profile owner (“Would you like to go on a date with this person?”). After answering this question, the next profile will be presented and the same procedure follows. When all three profiles are evaluated and responses messages are written to all of them, participants will be thanked, debriefed, and allowed to leave comments, suggestions, and questions.

q11.value: Our minimum sample size is 300 full responses.

q12.value: To determine the minimum sample size to test our hypotheses, we conducted power calculations by using an (Monte Carlo) power analysis application for mediation models (Schoemann, Boulton, & Short, 2017). For a mediation analysis with multiple mediators, a sample size of 260 should be sufficient (target power = .8, standardized coefficients a = .2, b = .2 and c’ = .1, correlation between mediators = .5). Therefore, we aim for a minimum of 300 participants.

q13.value: As soon as we meet our target sample size of 300 participants and an additional 10%, we will terminate data collection.

question.value:
In this study, we have three conditions:
(1) occurrence of two metaphors in profile text
(2) occurrence of two puns in profile text
(3) no metaphors and puns in profile text

Perception task
For the perception part of this study, we have six outcome variables. Two are mediating variables (perceived intelligence, sense of humor), and four are dependent variables (physical, social, and romantic attractiveness, and dating intention). All variables will be measured by one item, and except for dating intention all variables will be measured on a seven-point Likert scale. Dating intention will be measured by a binary yes/no question. The three dimensions of attractiveness we will measure are:
(1)	Physical attractiveness (McCroskey & McCain, 1974) 
(2)	Social attractiveness (McCroskey & McCain, 1974), 
(3)	Romantic attractiveness (Campbell, 1999)

The fourth outcome variable dating intention will be measured by a binary yes/no question, that is, “Would you like to go on a date with this person?”.  

The two mediating variables are: 
(5) Perceived intelligence (Leach, Ellemers, & Barreto, 2007)
(6) Perceived sense of humor (following Brand, Bonatsos, D’Orazio, & DeShong, 2012)

Production task
The response messages in the production task will be coded on whether there are (a) metaphors and (b) puns used in the response message.

In the perception task of this study, we measure three different dimensions of attractiveness: physical, social, and romantic attractiveness. With a Spearman’s correlation test, we will determine which dimensions of attraction can be clustered for further analyses. A reliability coefficient of .65 is considered as acceptable to cluster the dimensions of attractiveness.

Perception task
To analyze the perception data, we will do multilevel mediation analyses. The independent variables will be whether a profile contains metaphors (yes/no) or puns (yes/no). The ratings of profile owner’s perceived intelligence and sense of humor are the mediating variables, and the response variables are the scores on the attractiveness variables (3 or less dependent on the correlation; See Indices) and dating intention.
As such, we will test the following mediation hypotheses:
-	The effect of metaphor use on perceived attractiveness and dating intention is mediated by perceived intelligence (H1a)
-	The effect of pun use on perceived attractiveness and dating intention is mediated by perceived intelligence and sense of humor (H1b)

To test the mediation hypotheses, we will look at both the direct and mediating effects. Besides examining the mediating effect, we will also look at the direct effects of the independent variables on the mediating variables and of the mediating variables on the response variable. As such, it could be investigated to what extent the mediator explains the, potentially observed, mediation effect. 

Production task
To test H2a and H2b, we will do a chi-square test with as binary categorical variables the occurrence of metaphors (yes/no) or puns (yes/no) in the profile text and whether the response message included metaphors (yes/no) or puns (yes/no). 
As such, we will test H2a and H2b: 
- Main effect of metaphors in the profile text on the use of metaphors in the response message (to test H2a) 
- Main effect of puns in the profile text on the use of puns in the response message (to test H2b)

To test the moderating effect of profile owner’s perceived attractiveness in H3a and H3b, we will do a logistic regression with as (binary) independent variable the occurrence of metaphors and puns in the judged profiles, as (binary) dependent variable the occurrence of metaphors and puns in the response messages, and as moderating variable the (continuous) attractiveness scores. As such, we will test:  
- The moderating effect of the profile owner’s perceived attractiveness on the use of metaphors in the response message (to test H3a) 
- The moderating effect of the profile owner’s perceived attractiveness on the use of puns in the response message (to test H3b)

q19.value: For the two-tailed statistical analyses we do, we use an alpha level of .05 as our inferential cutoff. Further, we will look into the confidence intervals (95%) and see whether they exceed 0. We will also report effect sizes.

q20.value:
As our variables are measured within-subjects, we will only include data of the participants who completed the experiment. 

We will exclude participants only if we have any reason to believe that they did not follow the instructions, especially regarding the production task (e.g., using only the same words/phrases).

q21.value: During the experiment, participants cannot skip any statements and will be able to continue to the next profile when rated all statements. Participants are always allowed to stop without reason.

q22.value:
In addition to hypotheses testing, we will also do some exploratory analyses. If results of these exploratory analyses will be described, they will be described and listed as exploratory. 

In addition to personality perceptions about the profile owner’s intelligence and sense of humor, participants will also rate the profile owner’s perceived creativity. It has previously been argued that metaphors and puns are not only considered original and creative textual elements, but also that creativity is a personality trait desired in a potential romantic partner. To get a better view on the relationship between metaphors and puns, perceived creativity and attractiveness, creativity perceptions are also questioned. 

In addition to coding the response messages on the number of metaphors and puns included, we will also look for other evidence in their response messages that is indicative of being influenced by the occurrence of metaphors and puns in the input. These include: explicit reference to making jokes / using ‘figurative speech’ or explicit reference to perceptions of creativity, intelligence, and sense of humor. We will also investigate whether participants, in their response message, use the same metaphors/puns as the writer of the text to which they respond, or construct new/novel metaphors and/or puns.

For both the perception and production task, we will add the demographic variables (i.e., gender, age, level of education, Dutch as native language, years on dating site) as factors and will examine whether each of those variables affect the results.  

If we carry out other analyses to try and explain the results, then these analyses are exploratory and will be listed as such.

attributes.title: Health literacy in the context of pandemic and epidemic (outbreak): rapid scoping review
attributes.description: We aim to identify all relevant findings of studies investigating health literacy in epidemic/pandemic outbreak situations (apart from HIV related research), thematically group them and to subsequently identify knowledge gaps, which can be addressed speedily by future research.

q1.value: Uwe Matterne, Nina Egger, Christian Apfelbacher, Jonas Lander, Eva Maria Bitzer, Marie Luise Dierks

q2.value: HL is a key parameter in the process of disease prevention, treatment or management [1]. This scoping review sets out a) to systematically collect research dealing with HL in the context of epidemic/pandemic outbreak situations, b) to assess the methodologies and theoretical frameworks applied in these studies, and c) to determine the main research trends and gaps in the existing studies and to provide suggestions for future research.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q1: Uwe Matterne, Nina Egger, Christian Apfelbacher, Jonas Lander, Eva Maria Bitzer, Marie Luise Dierks
registration_responses.q2: HL is a key parameter in the process of disease prevention, treatment or management [1]. This scoping review sets out a) to systematically collect research dealing with HL in the context of epidemic/pandemic outbreak situations, b) to assess the methodologies and theoretical frameworks applied in these studies, and c) to determine the main research trends and gaps in the existing studies and to provide suggestions for future research.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
